nodes.text: Applying statistical physics to monetary transactions: money obeys conservation in agent-to-agent transactions and this conservation implies a statistical equilibrium distribution that explains inequality

Money is a digital accounting tool (medium of exchange, measure and store of value) whose functionality requires that ordinary agents cannot create or destroy money, so money is conserved in peer-to-peer transactions

By analogy with energy conservation in statistical physics, if money is conserved and transactions obey time-reversal symmetry or are additive, the equilibrium probability distribution of money P(m) is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)

The Boltzmann kinetic equation for money transfers and its small-transfer limit, the Fokker-Planck equation, provide a dynamical derivation of the stationary exponential distribution when detailed balance or constant drift/diffusion hold
Result: Additive transaction models and models satisfying microscopic time-reversal symmetry yield stationary exponential money distribution with money temperature equal to mean money per agent

Claim: Multiplicative transaction rules (e.g., transfers proportional to agent balance) break time-reversal symmetry and produce non-exponential (Gamma-like) stationary distributions and power-law tails
Evidence/result from data: Income distributions in the U.S. show a two-class structure â€” majority described by an exponential distribution and a high-income tail described by a Pareto power law

Claim: The exponential distribution follows from the principle of maximum entropy subject to fixed total money; entropy increases irreversibly toward maximal value producing inequality even among statistically identical agents

Claim: Wealth (money plus valued physical holdings) is fundamentally different from money because wealth changes via price changes or production and is not conserved in transactions; kinetic transfer models should refer to money, not wealth

Claim/Evidence: Debt is distinct from money (a promissory layer): borrowing creates paired money and debt obligations (particle-antiparticle analogy) that remove the lower boundary and, without restrictions, cause unbounded spread of net worth distribution and instability

Claim: Commercial banks do not truly 'create money' exogenously but create debt/liabilities for customers; reserve requirements and money-multiplier constraints are soft in practice, so banks can expand credit and debt widely

Evidence/Result: Quantitative easing and central bank bailouts inject exogenous money into the system via the banking sector, empirically associated with increases in the income share and measured inequality spikes (supporting that monetary rescue benefits the upper class)

Conclusion/Claim: The lend-crash-bailout cycle implies that large-scale capitalist monetary profits and ability to pay interest ultimately depend on exogenous state money injections (central bank monetization and state action)

Assumption/Claim: Boundary conditions (e.g., nonnegative money balances m >= 0 or regulated debt limits) are essential for a stationary money distribution and for stability; without such boundaries equilibrium is not reached

Conclusion: Closer attention to conservation laws, explicit layering (monetary, physical, promissory), and statistical equilibrium concepts can clarify economic fallacies and improve economic modeling
